author: Reuters Editorial
title: UK apologizes to Libyan ex-rebel and wife over role in 2004 rendition
text:
LONDON (Reuters) - Britain has apologized to Libyan former rebel Abdul Hakim Belhadj and his wife Fatima Boudchar over the role of British spies in their 2004 rendition from Thailand to Libya, where Belhadj was then tortured by Muammar Gaddafi’s henchmen.
FILE PHOTO: Abdul Hakim Belhadj of Libya's Homeland party speaks during a demonstration at the Ennahda party "Youth Festival" organized by the Renaissance Movement at the Conference Palace in Tunis December 23, 2012. The event is part of a celebration for the second anniversary of the Tunisian revolution. REUTERS/Anis Mili Attorney General Jeremy Wright said long-running legal claims brought by the couple against British officials and security agencies had now been withdrawn as part of a full and final settlement between them and the British government.
Boudchar, who was pregnant at the time of the rendition and was detained in Gaddafi’s Libya until shortly before giving birth, was in the public gallery in parliament with her son to hear Wright’s statement.
“Following mediation, the UK government has reached a full and final settlement of Mr Belhadj and Mrs Boudchar’s claims,” Wright said.
“No admissions of liability have been made by any of the defendants ... The government has agreed to pay Mrs Boudchar 500,000 pounds ($676,000).”
“The Prime Minister has now written to them both to apologize,” he said, adding that the British government believed Belhadj and Boudchar’s account of what had happened to them.
Reporting by Estelle Shirbon; editing by Stephen Addison
